body.p: The processor tries to fallback to a list of fonts, whenever a character is not covered by the font specified in the CSS. These fonts may or may be not available in the operating system.

These are the fallback fonts (they can change in future processor version), that are added automatically to the font-family CSS property, whenever one of the following font names are listed in that property:

ul.li: For SansSerif: Segoe UI, DejaVu Sans, Microsoft YaHei, Yu Gothic, Malgun Gothic, Latha, Arial Unicode MS
For Serif: Times, Times New Roman, DejaVu Serif, Symbol, SimSun, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Batang, Vijaya, Arial Unicode MS
For Monospace: Segoe UI, DejaVu Sans Mono, SimSun, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Malgun Gothic, Latha, Arial Unicode MS

body.p: In case you are using the processor on multiple operating systems/machines, make sure you have a consistent list of fonts installed on each of them. For instance if you are using a Linux and Windows machine to run transformations in parallel, and the PDF produced on Linux misses some characters (are replaced with the # symbol) while the Windows produced PDF is complete, then you can fix this by inspecting the fonts listed in the Document Properties dialog in PDF Reader and install them on the Linux machine (make sure you respect the font licensing terms).
